SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (✓) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Annie Babinhard

2. Your address: 44 Gladstone Ave. R. Saskatoon

3. Date: April 17

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Toronto Ont

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Cosmo McFarlane store keeper

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June - 1882

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: I was born in Toronto on 4/16/1881

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 21 months

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: My grandfather Dr. Smith bought land for the survey party in 1880 in the Carrot River district and called it the garden of Eden because it was so much more fruitful and had a good climate.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

My own homestead was the first taken up here for 100 miles. It was built east of 14, 25-4. That was taken up on June 7, 1882.

The house consisted of two rooms built of logs. The house was very simple, made of logs and roof that leaked like a sieve and had no floor. My mother brought some good furniture with her and made it into a real home. We were very happy there, and we had a good time. My sister Betty Roland was the first white baby born in the Yorkton district and she attended first.

   *My dad was a tree keeper in Toronto. Off West he farmed, was a auctioneer, worked in the Post Office, and did carpenter work. All the lakes kept fish, lots of game birds and wild fruit helped out and we had a good garden always.*
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Hot answer.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)? Yes

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

There was no mail service for over 6 months.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married on April 22, 1902 to W.S. de Balmhard, and have lived around Fort Macleod ever since.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes, my grandmother.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I remember a little of the Rebellion in 1886; all the settlers were in the storehouse having Church when the Indians came charging up the Chief raising white horses and shooting in the air, and all the white men were running away. I asked my father what we were doing why aren't we walking instead of just standing still in harm's way? My greatest excitement was my coming to be of age. My greatest excitement was my coming to be of age. May 8, 1889, I turned 18 years old first day of school.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We went to Church every time we had a minister, day or night whatever church he belonged to. Remember going to Church in a hay rack drawn by oxen lots of times. Donkey back was too heavy and God knew how to get help if put me in so that it stayed on Sunday a week day. There were very few women in the County at first and lots of young men so we used to have lots of men visits for meals especially on Sundays. My Brother started a Sunday service each Sunday afternoon.
3. How many did you bring to relatives or friends in your old home?

There were no records.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Mrs. DeBalinhard and Mr. William DeBalinhard, April 9, 1892, in Salt Lake City.

21. Did anyone else come to Baskettown because of your recommendation? Yes, my grandsons.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? Remember a little?

The Rebellion, in 1886; see the details written on the back of this page.

We had to travel through white horse and oxen teams, marking our way. The Chief, wearing white horse and oxen teams, marked our way. We had to travel with a mule, loaded with our supplies. The work was hard and we often went without food. We traveled over rough roads and had to help each other.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

We went to church every Sunday and helped to keep the meetings going. We traveled on a regular basis.

There were very few women in the Camp at first. Then it started to grow. I remember seeing a woman on the road.

There were lots of young men who used to have lots of fun.
25. When was the first car used in the community? — 1900

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? He car

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? At first Whitewood

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

In 1891 the Railway came into Yorkton and the old town moved to the Railroad.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? At first twice a year we got no supplies

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? As soon as Mr. Pearson opened his store on the old town as the mail was carried by horse then and came in each Sunday.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

There was no such thing as mail order catalogue but my mother used to get a few things from Toronto from stores she knew there. We did not have much money so those ways as they crops was to freeze and the flour from prairie wheat was very dark we did have a flour mill here built by the farmer from mill here called the Home White Rose Colonization Co. They called it Black Rose and most people used to call it Black Rose.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

For 1904. It was a private one owned by Mr. Paul.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

My Mother said she stayed because she never got warm enough to go back to Toronto and for another thing my health was so much better up in the West. Our first Doc was Doctor J. D. Stevenson who came up with Major Watson in 1875. The people were

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My Dad was the first Overseer of Yorkton, was the first Secretary of the School Board here in town, was Church Warden for 26 years. He was always a great man for politics, himself, belong to the Red Cross, done a long service back from Ross of our local Benevolent Society and was active.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

member in the Church. My Parfle started the R.C.A.F. in the Yorkton district.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

We have 3 children, I am 2 daughters. Son Ted is sole owner for the short time. He was a doctor in the last war. We had 4 years overseas, returned here in Saskatoon. Husband Jack Steele is manager of the fruit department of the Western Grocer in Saskatoon. They have 4 daughters, 2 working in Saskatoon, 2 are teachers.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The third daughter, Mary lives in Yorkton. Her husband works for Brownlee in Yorkton. She was in the R.C.A.F. for 4 years. She had 2 years overseas. She has one little boy. Our son Ted has 3 children, 1 girl and 2 boys—all going to school.
